headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Trump's Dinner with Supremacist; Volcano Erupts After Nearly 40 Years; Woman Found after 51 Years. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Should he apologize? Do you think that more Republicans --

utterances.speaker: ROMNEY
utterances.sentences: Oh, he doesn't - he -- he never sees anything wrong in anything he does. So, this is characteristic of his approach, which is either say it was a joke or say he didn't know what was happening. But that doesn't fly, obviously. This is something which degrades him, frankly, to do what he's done and - and it is something which diminishes the country as well. It's very unfortunate.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The strong criticism of Trump's judgment isn't just coming from the halls of Capitol Hill, but also down in Georgia, where I spoke with the Republican governor, Brian Kemp, yesterday.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) GOV. BRIAN KEMP (R-GA): And that was a bad decision. There's no place for that in the Republican Party. I know he's got, you know, his answer to that question, and I'll let him speak to that. But my views on that are very clear. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's not just in Capitol Hill. It's not just in Georgia. The criticism is also coming from those who worked for Trump in the White House. Jason Greenblatt, who served as Trump's envoy to the Middle East, praised Trump's record in a CNN opinion piece this morning, but said the dinner, quote, should not have happened, period. Greenblatt said that he hopes Trump condemns Fuentes and West for, quote, what they are, haters of Jews and haters of the foundations of the United States of America. Greenblatt calling Fuentes dangerous to the United States.But perhaps the strongest condemnation came from Trump's number two, his former number two, Vice President Mike Pence, who says his former boss should apologize. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) MIKE PENCE, FORMER U.S. VICE PRESIDENT: President Trump was wrong to give a white nationalist, an anti-Semite and a Holocaust denier a seat at the table. And I think he should apologize for it, and he should denounce those individuals and their hateful rhetoric without qualification. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Let's bring in CNN's senior political analyst John Avlon and CNN anchor and correspondent and host of the fantastic new podcast "The Assignment with Audie Cornish," Audie Cornish.Thank you both for being here.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Good morning.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So that was -- we were talking yesterday on the program about where are these Republican voices in Congress. It took a few days but they're there. And there's a lot of them. But missing, there's a big ones missing, too. Where is Kevin McCarthy, who, in February, called out Marjorie Taylor Greene and Paul Gosar in Congress for speaking at Fuentes' white nationalist conference, called it unacceptable, no place for our party to have this then. What about now?

utterances.speaker: AUDIE CORNISH, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm glad you're bringing up that event because that is supposed to be -- Fuentes, in his mind, creating an alternative to CPAC and has had luminaries of the extreme right there. And Marjorie Taylor Greene spoke there, right, was brought to - after chants of, you know, yeah Putin, or whatever.So, I think the real issue is, what exactly does this mean, if anything, based on what we've seen in the last couple of months, for the power of someone like Marjorie Taylor Greene, right? We've seen Kevin McCarthy talking about the last couple of days, the people he wants to elevate, the voices he wants to support. And now here's a perfect example why people had very serious questions about supporting this particular person, and now the rubber meets the road about what it means to be leader.

utterances.speaker: JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right. I mean if you - if you look at Kevin McCarthy, you know, the two titles is -- words in his title are, you know, leader and speaker. He's not leading. And he's not speaking out. And that's because he's constrained by the dynamics of the caucus he's desperately trying to lead or corral is probably a better term.But if you can't condemn this, you actually are incapable of leading. If you can't condemn this, which is one of the lowest bars you can possibly imagine, yes, the former president and current person running for president again shouldn't have had dinner and invited into his home a notorious white supremacist, Holocaust denier, and anti-Semite, what can you condemn? And so it's great that Republicans are stepping up, particularly in the Senate, particularly Mitt Romney. But we've come to expect that from Romney. Every else still tiptoeing, finding a way to rationalize.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: And then there's the folks who are still silent. Grow a spine, people, this isn't hard.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, and, listen, to -- to Poppy's point, it took a while.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Uh-huh.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I mean they stuck their finger up to sort of see which way the wind was blowing with this.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And it took a while.Look, I think it's - I think that there should be so many people speaking out that if we ran it, you know, it would take all day to get all of the sound bites on CNN for people.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think he went even further than Mitt Romney. And I don't know if that's because he's running for president. I don't know what - he has, you know, presidential hopes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Can I come back to Pence for a second.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. CORNISHAnd you do have to ask whether or not a dinner like this happens because there are fewer and fewer people who will say "no" to the things that do not make sense for the former leader of the free world to be doing. And is that how you end up at a dinner like that?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think the answer is self-evident. I mean the answer is, no.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: It's all team crazy all the time. That's all who's left.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: But that's implications for this campaign, right, going forward?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Of course, it does. This is - this is what a second Trump term would look like. And it's Donald Trump's impulse, right? This desire to never offend anyone who might say anything positive about him and what are (ph) crazy, far-out and extremist they may be.And that will be the undoing. We're already seeing it in real time.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But can I say one thing that stood out to me on that front yesterday. Listening to these Republicans, seeing these statements come in as they were -- returned to Capitol Hill, they knew they were going to get asked about this by reporters. So many of them blamed it on staffing issues and they always sidestep the issues.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I covered Trump. This is always what happens. When it's his attorneys, they blame Rudy Giuliani for something that was said. When it's something like this, they say, I don't know who let him in the door. Well, it was Trump.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's his club. He hosted. It's a private club. It's not like a Ruby Tuesday's where anyone can just go in and have dinner. And I think that is something that stood out to me as, even when there are Republicans criticizing him, he still (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Super fair.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: And I don't think it was an unwitting - you know what I mean -

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I've seen some sort of like - he - how could he have known who came to - like, I can't go to dinner with a former president without someone checking me out. So that makes no sense.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Sir, this is (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: He still has Secret Service. He still has the Secret Service around him.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And aren't these people supposed to be vetted? That was a point we were making yesterday. Should they -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Kaitlan, do they vet? Would they vet -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: They don't vet if you're like an anti-Semite or not. They vet if you have like weapons or a questionable criminal background.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, but like Google machine works and I think you would see something that doesn't make any sense to do.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's a -

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Google machine.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Neither is - neither is -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: It's like a very quick thing.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Line of the morning.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Neither Conte (ph) nor - nor - nor Nick Fuentes were exactly unknown in these corridors.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's the thing.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: But - but to your point, it's this - and you could hear it from some of the senators, the still impulse to find rationalizations, to deflect blame. He is a 70-plus-year-old man who was a former president of the United States and we continue to infantilize him. And it's totally absurd.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This - isn't this, to your earlier point, John, about McCarthy, I mean isn't this McCarthy essentially acknowledging his view that the ends justify the means?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: A hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And it's now incumbent upon Republicans in the House to decide if that's worth it for them.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Yes. But - but -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I think they've decided that.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: They've decided.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Right. This is -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Well, making -

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: I mean - well, I - no, I -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Despite the statements they'll make saying this should be our - be our new speaker.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Well, how to assess a statement. Do they ever mention his name? Do they ever say what needs to be done? Do they ever say if they would do it? If you don't hear any of those things in somebody's condemnation, it's not really a condemnation.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And then they - the knee jerk is he's - but, it's not an anti- Semite. No one asked if he was an anti-Semite. They just thought, is it appropriate for him to be doing what he's doing?

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Right. And this is all about vote counting ahead of the January 3rd vote, right? You know, this is the -- McCarthy can't afford to lose anybody. So, he's terrified of alienating even the people who might defend Nick Fuentes and - and Kanye, let alone offending Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, he needs their votes.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: That's right. That's (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: John Avlon, Audie Cornish, it was a great conversation. Thank you both.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys, very much.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, guys.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Up next, something very different but something you've got to see. The world's largest active volcano erupting in Hawaii for the first time in nearly four decades.Also this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) STEPHEN COLBERT, HOST, "THE LATE SHOW WITH STEPHEN COLBERT": There you go. There you are with your co-hosts. How did you -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I feel like - I feel like - COLBERT

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: The turtleneck is very Christmassy too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's - I like -

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: It's very Andy Williams Christmas special.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I'll be home --

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: How do you want people to feel in the morning, because a lot of these shows - and obviously you're a new show - but when the people first get up in the morning, you know, what's the vibe you want to give people?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) about my night, straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: AVLON
utterances.sentences: Andy Williams Christmas special.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: The world's largest volcano is erupting for the first time in almost 40 years. Boy, as you can hear and see, lava is flowing down the side of the volcano. The images come out of the Mauna Loa on Hawaii's big island. Officials are telling surrounding communities that they are not in imminent danger, as of now.Let's bring in, though, our chief climate correspondent, Mr. Bill Weir. Good morning to you. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: BILL WEIR, CNN CHIEF CLIMATE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Good morning, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Bill, 40 years and then this. What is this?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: This is so thrilling. I can't even tell you. The volcanologists have been waiting.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: This is one of the most measured volcanos in the world.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Volcanologists.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Volcanologists have been waiting for this event for a long time. They're studying it intensely. And native Hawaiians. And I'll explain that in a second.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: But this is not the kind of volcano that spews big ash clouds, like we saw in Iceland or other parts in the South Pacific. It's the kind that sort of oozes this mesmerizing lava. There's fountains, small and large, popping that magma up there. The park - Volcanoes National Park is open with some restrictions today. So, the people who are lucky enough to be there are going to see this.And here is why native Hawaiians are so excited. Take a look at this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Speaking in Foreign Language).WEIR (voice over): Lucca (ph) is a native Hawaiian practitioner on Kilauea. The most active of the volcanoes on the big island.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (Speaking in Foreign Language).

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Imagine if the whole world looked at their environment as their grandmother, or their father. They'll treat them very differently, you know? And so that's how we try and treat our environment in that same way. We look at them as family.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: To Hawaiians, Volcanoes National Park is as sacred as the Vatican to Catholics or Mecca to Muslims.WEIR (on camera): We are headed to pay our homage to Pele. As we head towards the glow on the horizon of the Kilauea volcano and it's about 4:00 a.m. and the line of tourists is already here as people race to get their best viewing spots to see splatters of magma and hopefully a glimpse into the lava lake. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: That's from "The Wonder List," now streaming on Discovery Plus, by the way. But it's so cool that the tourists will actually get to experience the double eruption right now.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: By the way, for clarification, you said a big ash with an a-s-h cloud, right?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: I said - well, it goes both ways. It goes both days. This is big ash clouds.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You saw - you -- we saw in what you just showed, you said rearranging neighborhoods, right?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So how do they know, volcanologists, how do officials know that this is not a threat to (INAUDIBLE)?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: They can measure sort of the seismic activity, the number of volcanoes - or earthquakes doubled in -- since September. So, they know something's coming but they still don't know precisely when it will pop.Right now the lava's flowing northward. Most of the communities are to the south. That can shift. But the biggest concern really is - is what's in the air. The gases that come off. And Pele's hair. That's these thin strands of glass that if you breathe them can be really dangerous.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: But, right now, it looks like nobody's in any danger.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Fascinating. Always a pleasure. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Good to see you, Don.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Be safe. WEIR

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thanks for coming. I know, you like this?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: I like it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's nice.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: I like it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Bill Weir. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: You bet.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, on top of those remarkable images, we are also seeing an incredible reunion this morning. Fifty-one years in the making. A woman who had been kidnapped as a toddler finally got to meet her real family.Plus this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MUSIC
utterances.sentences: This could be love because I've had the time of my life.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So much. I love this movie so much, I was just telling them. The star of the classic film "Dirty Dancing" revealing which of our favorite characters will be seen in the sequel. That's right. There's a sequel.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Come on, Poppy. I can do it. You - we're going to do this!

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Don't.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are we going to do the lift?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good story.Well, this morning, a family in Texas has been reunited with their daughter more than 50 years after she was abducted when she was just 22 years (ph) old. A DNA match made this all possible. Let's go straight to CNN's Ed Lavandera in Dallas. Wow, what a story.

utterances.speaker: ED LAVANDERA, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Overwhelmingly emotional, this story.Melissa Highsmith was abducted when she was 22 months old. Her mother had hired a babysitter because she needed to go to work. The babysitter came to the house, took the child and they disappeared. Fifty-one years later, the parents get a DNA test. It comes back a few weeks ago that it is connected to their daughter's children. And that triggers a relationship that culminated this past weekend with the family reuniting. You can imagine what this family has been through in the last few days. And they've been talking about it since all of this news has broken. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MELISSA HIGHSMITH, KIDNAPPED AS A BABY
utterances.sentences: It is overwhelming, but, at the same - same time, it's -- it's just the most wonderful feeling in the world.

utterances.speaker: ALTA APANTENCO, MOTHER
utterances.sentences: I just couldn't believe it. I thought I would never see her again.

utterances.speaker: JEFFRIE HIGHSMITH, FATHER
utterances.sentences: And they said, dad, she's alive. And I started crying.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: Melissa Highsmith's parents had lived in Illinois for a time. They have been back in Fort Worth essentially parents and this woman had been living in the same town, had no idea. And now Melissa Highsmith is discovering that she has four other siblings and the family is going through this process of getting to know each other once again.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Ed, what about what happened to the babysitter?

utterances.speaker: LAVANDERA
utterances.sentences: Well, investigators in Fort Worth say that they will try to figure out more of the details as to what happened surrounding the circumstances of - of this abduction and kidnapping. So, it's not exactly clear. Melissa Highsmith has said in interviews that she confronted the woman she believed to be her mother for so long, and then things started spiraling, the story started unraveling after that. But what exactly is going to happen to this woman is not exactly clear. It sounds like the statute of limitations might have been - might have passed. It was 20 years. So, we will have to see exactly what Fort Worth Police do next. But they say they will continue to investigate the details surrounding this abduction.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Ed Lavandera, thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Senate lawmakers set to vote on landmark legislation today to protect same-sex marriages. What to expect, straight ahead.Plus, this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Why do you think there were 200,000 people that voted for you but not for Herschel Walker?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I was doing (INAUDIBLE).Hey! Wow! Oh, my gosh! (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I got to stay up way past my bedtime last night to hang out with Stephen Colbert of "The Late Show." We talked about this new gig here with these two folks and how it's been waking up early for us.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But, you know, it's - I can be a little bit grumpy. I can be a bitch in the morning.

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: Interesting.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Anybody can relate to that? I'm sure. Just being honest.

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: On CNN - on CNN are you allowed to say (EXPLETIVE DELETED) because you can't say it here?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's basic cable. You can say (EXPLETIVE DELETED).

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: You can say (EXPLETIVE DELETED)? Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, you can say (EXPLETIVE DELETED).

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.sentences: That's (EXPLETIVE DELETED). That's worth it right there.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Basic cable. You can say - and I've said - I've said much worse on - on CNN.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I was going to ask if you were g-rated, and you weren't.
